thread.title: Pearson Anderson CEO clears his name after wages scandal - Leicester Mercury

author: Lauren Mills
title: Pearson Anderson CEO clears his name after wages scandal - Leicester Mercury
text:
Pearson Anderson CEO clears his name after wages scandal Amit Kainth explains that Pearson Anderson is in the clear despite Govenment list Share Amit Kainth, the chief executive of Pearson Anderson has cleared his company's name Share Comments 
A Leicester business man is keen to clear his name after being listed by the Government as one of more than 200 companies underpaying workers. 
Amit Kainth, the chief executive of recruitment firm Pearson Anderson, was said by the Government to owe £49,800 to 169 staff. The full list of 233 companies was published by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy on August 16. Read More 
Mr Kainth said: “Pearson Anderson help and support workers by loaning money for transport, criminal record checks and training. Amit Kainth with his staff at Pearson Anderson 
“The money advanced to the worker prior to commencing employment will then be deducted from their wages in instalments during the course of the employment. 
“When HMRC came to look at our books in December 2015 they said it was acceptable to deduct money for transport, criminal records and accommodation and take workers below National Minimum Wage, but it is not OK to deduct for training because this is not classed as third party. Read More Soft Touch Arts launches fund raising art auction 
“Our solicitors failed to notify Pearson Anderson of the third party act and as a result we had to pay back to all the workers the training money which had been deducted. 
“The case with HMRC was resolved last year in March 2016 and I can confirm all workers were paid back in June 2016. 
“We now have a claim against our legal firm who advised us incorrectly. City Gate House, Pearson Anderson's new Leicester HQ 
Pearson Anderson recently moved into new offices in City Gate House, close to Leicester city centre. 
Now that Mr Kainth has cleared his name regarding the wages scandal, he said he planned to build the business with a view to floating it on London’s AIM market in due course. 
He said: “Pearson Anderson is currently turning over £10 million a year and is continuing grow. 
“We are currently in the process of searching for a company we can merge with to float on the market. 
“With Brexit fast approaching, Pearson Anderson has during the course of this year been working with global partners in India, Philippines and Sri Lanka in a bid to extend its reach to find qualified nurses to overcome the shortfall clients are facing in the UK in both the public and private sector.” Like us on Facebook
